definitions.definition: not in or to any place

examples.text: I had nowhere to live, so I was sleeping on my sister's couch.
There was nowhere for me to sit.
‘Where are you going this weekend?’ ‘Nowhere special.’
She doesn't want to stay there but she has nowhere else to go.
Nowhere do plants flourish with such vigour as they do in tropical rainforests.
This animal is found in Australia, and nowhere else.
Nowhere is the effect of government policy more apparent than in agriculture.

definitions.definition: in a sudden and surprising way

examples.text: A huge flock of sheep seemed to appear from nowhere.
The attack came from nowhere.

definitions.definition: to make no progress or have no success; to not enable somebody to make progress or have success

examples.text: We discussed it all morning but got nowhere.
Talking to him will get you nowhere.
His career was **going nowhere fast**.
The campaign over pay and conditions was getting nowhere.

definitions.definition: to have no successful result for somebody

examples.text: This discussion is leading us nowhere.
Often there are discoveries which lead nowhere.

definitions.definition: a place that is a long way from other buildings, towns, etc.

examples.text: She lives on a small farm in the middle of nowhere.
The job doesn't pay anywhere near enough for me.
Older cars are nowhere near as fuel-efficient as modern cars.
Older cars are nowhere near as fuel-efficient as modern cars.

definitions.definition: impossible for anyone to find or see

examples.text: I wanted to talk to him but he was **nowhere to be found**.
The children were nowhere to be seen.
A peace settlement is nowhere in sight *(= is not likely in the near future)*.
